text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with orange creme anglaise
that's right creme anglaise is what the
French pastry chefs call English cream
and I don't think any of us blame them
and I promised I would show you this
super simple custard sauce when it was
featured in our Valentine's Day souffle
video so here it is and as you'll see it
could not be simpler so step one we're
gonna put a cup of heavy cream into a
heavy-bottomed saucepan we're gonna add
some white sugar 2 egg yolks a little
bit of vanilla and a tablespoon of Grand
Marnier and by the way we're only doing
that because this is an orange creme
anglaise if you want vanilla creme
anglaise which is the classic you would
just use a whole split vanilla bean in
this alright but we're doing orange so
we're gonna give that a mix we're gonna
turn our heat on to medium maybe
slightly under medium not quite medium
low what is that medium medium-low I
don't know you know what I'm saying just
a little less than medium we're gonna
switch to a spatula and we're simply
gonna stir and wait and I know there's a
ton of different techniques for doing
this out there and they're all
unfortunately usually way more
complicated than this so I really like
this sort of stripped down method
there's no tempering the eggs there's no
pouring back and forth we're just gonna
make it with the fewest moving parts
possible and it's gonna be perfect
you'll see so we're just gonna keep
stirring with the spatula making sure
the flat of the spatula is scraping the
bottom at all times kind of a figure 8
is a good way to go maybe throw in a
couple figure fours up to you I would
not suggest a figure 5 though I tried
that once pulled a muscle my ring finger
so just stir in a slow figure 8 and
what's gonna happen is this mixture
heats up the egg yolks will thicken it
and then we'll be done it's pretty much
it so we're not gonna let this simmer
it's gonna come up below the simmer it's
gonna be about a hundred and eighty
degrees if your into that whole
temperature thing but really all you
need to do is look for the thickening
and you'll notice when you first start
stirring those little whirlpools and
eddies kind of disappear quickly but as
it heats up and as it thickens slightly
those little Eddie's and whirlpools
actually take longer to disappear you'll
actually be able to feel the viscosity
get thicker as you stir so right here I
could feel the thickness was just about
what I wanted and it's not really easy
to see but right there on the surface
you'll notice these little slightly
darker streaks
another telltale sign you're done so I'm
going to turn off the heat at this point
and we're gonna check it with a spoon
and what you need to have happen it has
to coat the back of a spoon and hold a
finger mark all right so you can see the
thickness there and if I run my finger
across the back of the spoon all right
it holds that mark that means it's done
congratulations
so at that point you're gonna strain it
immediately through a fine mesh strainer
all right worst case scenario if there
were any tiny tiny particles of egg that
stuck to the bottom and cook too much
they will get strained out of course I
could show you the inside of my strainer
but trust me mine was perfect and then
we're just gonna let it cool this is a
sauce served ice-cold it kind of has a
little bit of a thickness to it now but
you'll see this will thicken
significantly as it cools so if you're
thinking it's too thin don't worry okay
so we're gonna let that cool while we're
waiting we might as well flavor it up
with a little more orange I'm gonna put
in some freshly grated orange zest
there's nothing like it and yes we did
add some of that orange cognac when we
were on the stovetop but right here I do
want to add a little small splash which
i think is sort of the secret ingredient
and that orange creme anglaise is done
and of course once it's cold this can be
used on a million different things this
makes a great sauce for all kinds of
pastries it's particularly amazing next
to some chocolate cake and as you
witness with your own eyes perfect for a
dessert soufflé so I really hope you
give that a try
head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredients and more info as usual
and as always enjoy
[Music]
you
